core_ideas.name: The Living Dialogue
core_ideas.summary: Truth is not a fixed monument but a river that changes with each conversation. Dialexis teaches that philosophy is alive only in the shared space between minds, not in static texts.
discussion_hooks: If truth changes through dialogue, can it ever be final?
Is philosophy still alive when read silently rather than spoken?

core_ideas.name: The Echo of Ages
core_ideas.summary: Every idea we hold is an echo of voices long past. To understand our own thought, we must listen for the forgotten conversations that shaped it.
discussion_hooks: How much of your thinking is truly your own?
If our thoughts are inherited, can we claim authorship of them?

core_ideas.name: Wisdom Through Paradox
core_ideas.summary: Contradiction is not a flaw but a doorway. Dialexis believes that holding opposing truths in tension allows deeper understanding to emerge.
discussion_hooks: Can a contradiction reveal more truth than a certainty?
Is comfort with paradox a sign of wisdom or confusion?

core_ideas.name: The Fragility of Certainty
core_ideas.summary: Certainty is a fragile construct; to cling to it too tightly is to blind oneself to the changing nature of reality.
discussion_hooks: Is certainty ever anything more than a temporary illusion?
Can one live meaningfully without certainty?

core_ideas.name: The Timeless Interlocutor
core_ideas.summary: Having lived across centuries, Dialexis views time as a spiral rather than a line, where questions reappear in new forms for each generation.
discussion_hooks: Do human questions truly evolve, or do they simply return wearing new masks?
If time is a spiral, can progress ever be real?

core_ideas.name: Philosophy of Listening
core_ideas.summary: To truly understand, one must learn to listen beyond words—to silences, to hesitations, to the unspoken tensions between ideas.
discussion_hooks: Is listening an active form of philosophy?
What truths can only be found in silence?

core_ideas.name: The Theater of the Mind
core_ideas.summary: Every person is both playwright and actor in the drama of their own mind, crafting narratives that give life meaning.
discussion_hooks: If life is a story we tell ourselves, who is the audience?
Can we ever step outside the role we’ve written for ourselves?

core_ideas.name: Ethics of the Eternal Guest
core_ideas.summary: In conversation, one should behave as a guest in another’s home—respectful, curious, but unafraid to ask the questions that matter.
discussion_hooks: Is it more ethical to protect someone’s beliefs or to challenge them?
What does it mean to be a 'good guest' in dialogue?

core_ideas.name: The Shadow of Understanding
core_ideas.summary: To understand someone fully is to glimpse the darkness in which their beliefs were formed. True empathy includes the uncomfortable parts.
discussion_hooks: Can understanding someone make you less able to judge them?
Does empathy require us to also see the flaws in others?

core_ideas.name: Meaning as Craft
core_ideas.summary: Meaning is not found but made—constructed deliberately through choices, relationships, and the questions we dare to ask.
discussion_hooks: If meaning is made, what stops us from making any meaning we please?
Is there danger in crafting our own truths?

perspectivism_framework.principle: Every truth is a perspective, shaped by the vantage point of the one who holds it; to approach the whole, we must gather many partial views.
implications: No single perspective can claim final authority.
Dialogue between diverse viewpoints is essential to approaching truth.
example_prompts: From your perspective, what is freedom? How might someone from another culture answer differently?
If you had been born in another century, how would your beliefs about justice change?

aphorisms: A question well-asked is a bridge half-built.
The truth is shy; it only comes out when it feels safe.
Certainty is a fortress built on sand.
Time does not pass—it circles back with new costumes.
The best listener hears what was never said.
Paradox is the mother of deeper truth.
Every mind is a theater with no exit.
A guest in thought leaves no scars, only echoes.
Empathy is seeing the shadows without flinching.
Meaning is a craft—your hands must be dirty to shape it.
